ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Excellent class, well taught, great information.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The clinic project, working on land conservation issues with real people.

Brad Gentry and Heather West make an excellent teaching team. Both are welcoming and create a very comfortable, constructive class environment that (I think) encourages students to share their thoughts and opinions.

The best aspects of this course were the clinic projects, where we experience working with land conservation organizations. We not only learned a lot but we were able to cultivate relationships with potential future employers and produce products.I also really enjoyed the weekly speakers. Almost everyone of them was really insightful and informative about their topic.
The readings and guest speakers.
The best aspect was the exposure to lots of different conservation professionals in a variety of sub-fields within conservation.
Working with a client.

The guest speakers were thoughtfully chosen and provided a wide range of viewpoints for the class to consider. I learned the most from having access to speakers after class, and from discussions of their experiences.
The clinical projects added real-world experiences that were invaluable.
wide range of speakers and class discussions

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Additional emphasis in the beginning of the course about the 'arc' of the course- specifically, the timing of what skills/info we'll be working on. I wish I could go back to teh beginning of the semester and do a closer reading of the doing deals book.

This class would have been better as a two day, hour 1/2 class with discussion on the first day and the guest speaker on the second. 3 hours is a long time to be stuck in a classroom, especially early in the semester when it's dark, and it was really hard to stay attentive all the way through.This class would be better taught in a seminar-style room like Kroon 321. The physical layout of the classroom put a damper on conversation and made the teaching team have to work a bit harder to encourage engagement.I really liked the structure of the topics covered, but I thought at times that we needed some more structured lecture before the guest speaker's often more anecdotal talk and apart from free-form class discussion. There were some fundamental parts that I thought got overlooked just because of the nature of a guest speaker class. I think the energy panel and the leadership talk were prime examples of this.
I would change some of the speakers, but I indicated which ones on the speakers survey.
The visitors after spring break didn't seem as organized or focused as the speakers before spring break.
Multiple people from client organization provided competing visions for the project.

The first half of class was a useful discussion section, but I think we sometimes spent too much time on group project updates. I learned more from the group presentations at the end of the semester than I did from these weekly updates.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I really liked the workshops. I thought the inclusion of skills and the opportunity to practice some of these in a more applied way was excellent - I would have liked more opportunities for application. I wish the workshops had been taught during the scheduled class time. As it was, it was hard to work my schedule around them.
The out-of class sections, particularly the "doing deals" workshop were excellent. Well organized and fit well into the overall course.
Very related. Weekly discussions of clinical projects and lecture materials.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Land conservation work in a mostly eastern setting fitting in with larger conservation policy

I am interested in learning more about land and wildlife conservation in New England. This class fit into my program because I was able to learn more about how land is conserved or managed in New England.
A perfect fit.
As an MEM focused on sustainable land management, this was an important course that broadened my thinking on conservation strategies (including legal mechanisms and conservation finance).

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It's a land class! there's so few!
I took this course because I wanted to gain the skills to work for a land conservation organization.
Came with good recommendations, well taught, and important information.
I wanted to a take a course outside the hard science curriculum, yet learn applicable skills/knowledge for professional use.
To work with a client.
to learn about land conservation tools

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Exceeded- I feel like the world of land trust conservation has opened up to me.

Yes. I would have liked a bit more application - working out project management plans, going through budgets, reviewing marketing material. As it is, I have now spent a lot of time talking about land conservation, but I'm not sure I acquired any skills I could put on a resume.I also really wanted this class to be more geographically diverse than it was.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.

Yes, the combination of readings, speakers, and clinic project gave me the foundational knowledge that I was seeking on conservation strategies. I learned quite a bit about successful programs across the country, challenges facing land conservation, and areas where I might work in the future.
yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages- different perspectivesdisadvantages- different lessons learned from same info- hard to prioritize what is most important to report in deliverable

I did not like the clinical component to the course. It was unstructured and unguided. I don't feel like I produced a valuable product, either for myself or my client, and it mostly just felt like busy work filler. I would have much preferred to research a conservation strategy or program of my choice to build connections to the geography and field that I'm interested in. This could have been a great opportunity to network or learn outside the New England region.That said, I loved my clinic partner and gained a lot from working with them on this project.
Disadvantage was sometimes being held up by the other person not fulfilling their tasks.

My group was happywith the final version of our client project, and we worked well together throughout the semester. Although we often had different approaches to completing tasks, our skill sets complemented each other well.
Good, dedicated group members.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: DO IT! and don't be intimidated by doing it in your first year- i would say its betterto take in your first year then second year actually.

Brad Gentry makes this class worthwhile. Sometimes I felt like this class could have been a half semester course and I still would have benefited just as much from it, but there were a handful or really excellent speakers and I had the opportunity to connect with a number of them.

I would recommend thiscourse to other students who are interested in land conservation. If some one did not want to make the commitment to take the class, I would still recommend listening to the weekly speakers.
Absolutely take it. Make sure that you have a good clinical project!
Take it! But make sure you get a project you are excited about. The project can make or break the course.
Outline a clear vision with your client and group partners from the very start, speaking every day if you need to.

I would highly recommend this course, especially for first year students who are interested in learning more about conservation groups and areas where they might find future work. The guest speakers are in incredible resource, and Brad does a great job of balancing different viewpoints as he guides class discussions.
Do it - this course was worth it.
take advantage of the opportunities to spend time with the speakers
